oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: A 'Natural-Finish' Card -- Made Only by Gray & Thompson -- Chapel Hill, North Carolina

Message on back of card: "Dear Mam, I received your letter last week. We are on our way to Georgia. We stopped in Spruce Pine N.C. for the night. North Carolina. Variety Vacation Land. Harvested, Baled -- Cotton bales at Enfield, N.C., recently delivered by farmers, are shown here awaiting shipment to the textile mills in the western part of the state. oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Pub. by L.F. Whitaker

Message on back of card: "Every one has admired your sewing & they think you are so smart -- will tell you all the nice things that have been said about you when I return. Please make the guimp of my brown silk waist and send it to me within the next 2 wk. Make it by the guimp pattern that my blue silk dress is make by & exactly like it only pipe the cuffs with the solid brown. With love, Irma. If you think the waist will look better with cuffs of solid brown make them that way -- like the blue silk cuffs." Addressed to "Miss Zelma Lewter, Orlando, Fla." Postmarked 11 August 1911.

Message on front of card: "Do you remember this scene?" Message on back of card: "Aug. 22 - 11. Dear Miss Mary: How are you getting on these warm days? Hope you are enjoying your visit & getting a plenty good rest. Miss Mary, if you have a nice little jacket pattern that will do for a linen cool suit, will you please lend it, or rent it to me. I will return the favor. Would like to get it right away, guess it will be Sept. before I get away. Best wishes, Katie W.R." Addressed to "Miss Mary R. [Gons], 640 Cocoa St., Rocky Mt., N.C." oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Commercial Building, Gastonia, N.C.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Gastonia is located in almost the exact center of the Piedmont region. The air tempered by sunshine is pleasant and invigorating. In the City proper and its outskirts are 60 Textile Plants and the number of products manufactured here runs into the hundreds. Gastonia has modern school buildings, beautiful city parks, progressive civic clubs and many fine churches. It is located on U.S. Highway No. 29 and is only 2 hours driving distance to the beautiful Western North Carolina Mountains. Historic Kings Mountain Battlefield is only 20 miles West of the City. Pub. by the Asheville Post Card Co., Asheville, N.C.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Falls House, Gastonia, N.C.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: MacGown Cooke Ptg. Co. Chattanooga

Message on front of card: "I misplaced your address so you will have to send it to me. Think however this will reach you at Hiddenite. Goodbye for this time J. H. LaFou." Message on back of card: "Dear Mrs. Gill I arrived here safely yesterday aft. Train was late as we had to wait in C. for train from Richmond. Rivers were swollen high as we passed on our way to G. But we went over the Catawba safely. Train slowed up & crept along carefully. It was a relief when we were over the trestle. What rains we have had. Most unusual weather for the Carolinas. Heavy losses in So. Ca. too. Bridges washed away & lines lost. Georgia has suffered too. Hope you & new little girl keep well. Often think of the pleasant times we had together this summer & trust we shall meet again in the near future. Will not forget the pleasant evenings in yr. room when you entertained me so well. Drop me a line sometime. Shall be glad to hear from you. J. H. L." Addressed to: "Mrs. Gill., Hiddenite N.C., Davis White Sulphur Springs." Postmarked 28 August 1908.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:publisher: MacGowan Cooke Printing Co., Chattannooga, Tenn.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: View of a building partially hidden by trees. There are people on the front porch and a woman standing on the second-floor porch.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Dwellings; Porches;

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Guilford-Benbow, Greensboro, N.C.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Message on front of card: "July 22, 1906. Dear 'Babe' -- Took supper here tonight -- nice place. -- Mama will remember it. Won't Mama be surprised to see me at 5:15 in A.M.? [Rives] was well & fat and happy -- 4 teeth -- 2 upper, cutting more, chews all the time. I had a nice time but had to leave too soon. Dr. [Andwa] got $19000.00. Have missed you all. Elmer." Addressed to "Miss Ethel Shaffer, Raleigh, N.C." Postmarked 22 July 1906.
View of the dining room and lobby in the Guilford-Benbow hotel.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Greensboro, N.C. Guilford Court House
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Guilford Court House. Greensboro's first court house was of logs, and in connection with it were whipping post, stocks, and pillories. The first court was held in there in 1809; a permanent building was erected soon after, which was moved in a 1856 to new site, and was destroyed by fire in 1872. It was at once rebuilt in the same style of architecture at a cost of $21,000. Raphael Tuck & Sons, "Raphotype" [Regd.] Postcard. No. 5112, "Greensboro, N.C." Art publishers to their majesties the King and Queen.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The Rotograph Co., N.Y. City. Printed in Germany. 66474.

Message on back of card: "Have you forgotten me? I'm here at school, now are you coming to Greens. any time soon -- I'd be delighted to see you -- G. F. C. is a great place. Where is Vallie? oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Guards 200 Wrecks. Famous Diamond Lightship, stationed at the tip of Diamond Shoals, 12 miles off Cape Hatteras, N.C. oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Greetings from Laurinburg-Maxton Army Air Base, Maxton, N.C.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Official Photographs U.S. Army and Marine Corps. A "Natural Finish" Card Made by Graycraft Card Co., Danville, Va. F-129A.

Message on back of card: "May 9, 1943. Dear Lee: Well I guess I am finally assigned and settled till we go overseas which won't be very long. This is the most desolate spot I have struck, it's really a dump. Jackie Coogan the star is a glider pilot in this squadron and is a screwball. You can fly here in your spare time but we only have the C-47 transports and gliders so we don't do much flying as they are so clumsy. Lee don't forget to write and remember my request for a snapshot? I will try and drop you a line when I catch up on some of my writing. Your friend. Harold. Pfc Harold Kopenhover, 56TC Sq 375TC Sq., Army Air Base, Maxton, N.C." Addressed to "Miss Emily Fry, Davies House, Tufts College, Mass." Postmarked 9 May 1943.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:publisher: Graycraft Card Co., Danville, Va.;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Compostite view of a military base showing tanks, planes, jeeps, and a paratrooper.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The World Post Card Co., Philadelphia, Pa.

Message on front of card: "I teach in this building and room in another. Maude. Address -- James Sprunt Institute, Kenansville, N.C." Message on back of card: "Hello Rose: How are you, Willie & Paul? When are you going on your trip? I like N.C. all right. Am awfully interested in my work -- My! it's hot down here. I am about fifty miles from the sea coast. Send me a card & tell me how you are. I am fat & fine." Addressed to "Mrs. Will Stickley, Staunton, Augusta Co., Virginia. R.F.D. #6." Postmarked 14 September [1908].

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Kawana Lake, Linville, N.C., near Eseeola Inn
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Message on front of card: "This is where I spent yesterday. McGregor." Addressed to "Mr. J.P. Black, c/o Yale & Towns Mfg. Co., 9 Murray St., New York." Postmarked 6 August 1906.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:publisher: Yale & Towns Manufacturing Co., New York, N.Y.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: View of a man and a woman in a canoe on a lake. The woman is holding a parasol. A printed testimonial reads: "The Following is an Extract from a Letter written by an Angler who is Prominent in Cincinnati. Cincinnati, O., May 18, 1906. 'Our party of three spent several days at Linville last week. We took fifty-five trout out of the lake in one day, one of my friends getting the limit of twenty five. They were all speckled trout, three of them weighing two pounds each, the average being a little less than one pound each. Later we were not so fortunate though in the three following days we took one hundred and twenty in all. South of Canada there is no better trout fishing than in Kawana Lake.'"
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Lakes & ponds; Canoes; Umbrellas;
Postcards--North Carolina.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Message on front of card: "This is such a nice place for boat riding." Message on back of card: "Your card received. Am sorry you got stung one time. Taylor. Faison, N.C." Postmarked 2 August 1911.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The Albertype Co., Brooklyn, N.Y.

Message on back of card: "Well guess you think I have forgotten you again, but I have not. Am feeling fine and having a good time, but not such a time as I had this sumer when I was around Faison, N.C. Guess the [weather] is getting in your section by now. Sincerely, Oscar. 514 Florida Ave, Jaxonville, Fla." Addressed to: "Miss Maud Efland, Efland, N.C." There is no stamp or postmark on the back of the postcard.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Message on back of card: "My dear 'Gaston' how are you and the cats getting along? Am in Morganton for a few days and having a nice time. How is Grandpa.
